title: 114_s1989
content: The "Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015" may be cited as the short title. It addresses the treatment of direct primary care service arrangements. The "Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015" addresses the treatment of direct primary care service arrangements by amending the Internal Revenue Code to exclude such arrangements from being considered as health plans or insurance. The amendment excludes direct primary care service arrangements from being considered as insurance for tax purposes. Effective date is after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include periodic provider fees as medical care. This applies to taxable years after the Act's enactment. SEC. 4 establishes the Medicare Primary Care Medical Home Demonstration Program. Section 1115A of the Social Security Act is amended to include a Primary Care Medical Home Model where qualified practices are reimbursed a periodic fee for services provided to individuals enrolled under Medicare Part B. The Primary Care Medical Home Model under Section 1115A of the Social Security Act reimburses qualified practices with a periodic fee for services provided to individuals enrolled in Medicare Part B. A qualified direct primary care medical home practice is defined as described in section 1301(a)(3) of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. The Primary Care Medical Home Model reimburses qualified practices with a periodic fee for services provided to individuals enrolled in Medicare Part B. The Secretary establishes the fee for qualified direct primary care medical home practices participating in the model. The Primary Care Medical Home Model reimburses direct primary care practices with a periodic fee for services provided to Medicare Part B enrollees. The fee set by the Secretary cannot exceed twenty percent of the estimated monthly amount payable from the Federal Trust Funds for services. The Secretary establishes a performance benchmark using ACO quality measures in the Medicare shared savings program for services provided to Medicare Part B enrollees. The Secretary establishes a performance benchmark using ACO quality measures in the Medicare shared savings program for services provided to Medicare Part B enrollees. In the second year of the model, qualified direct primary care medical home practices participating in the model will undergo adjustments. In the second year of the model, qualified direct primary care medical home practices participating in the program may receive a 5 percent increase in the periodic fee for meeting or exceeding performance benchmarks. In the second year of the model, qualified direct primary care medical home practices may receive a 5 percent increase in the periodic fee for meeting performance benchmarks. If a practice does not meet the benchmark for two consecutive years, the fee will be reduced by 5 percent. The participation of a qualified direct primary care medical home practice in the model may be terminated if performance benchmarks are not met for 2 consecutive years. Each practice must provide specific activities and functions associated with direct primary care medical homes. Each qualified direct primary care medical home practice must provide preventive care, wellness counseling, primary care, coordination with specialty and hospital care, availability of ongoing care appointments 7 days per week, and secure e-mail and telephone consultation. The direct primary care medical home practice must offer coordination with specialty and hospital care, ongoing care appointments 7 days per week, secure e-mail and telephone consultation, and availability of telephone access for ongoing care consultation 24/7. The primary care provider panel size should support the scope of services provided. The primary care provider panel size should support the scope of services provided, with priority given to practices enrolling dual eligible individuals. The primary care provider panel size should prioritize enrolling dual eligible individuals, defined as those enrolled in part B of title XVIII and meeting specific criteria under the Social Security Act. The Social Security Act specifies that care provided in a qualified direct primary care medical home practice under a specific model is not considered insurance and is not regulated as such by State insurance commissioners. A qualified direct primary care medical home practice participating in the model under this subsection must report annually to the Secretary on the progress of individuals with chronic conditions, including emergency room visits, hospitalizations, and surgeries. Qualified direct primary care medical home practices participating in the model must report annually to the Secretary on individuals with chronic conditions, including emergency room visits, hospitalizations, surgeries, specialist visits, and use of advanced radiology. Additional areas may be determined appropriate by the Secretary. The Secretary will provide qualified direct primary care medical home practices with necessary patient data for clinical purposes and evaluation of the model. Providers currently opted out of Medicare may participate in a qualified direct primary care medical home practice under the model, and payment can be made for services provided to Medicare beneficiaries. Providers who have been excluded from federal health care programs are not allowed to participate in a qualified direct primary care medical home practice under the model. Providers excluded from federal health care programs cannot participate in a qualified direct primary care medical home practice under the model for a minimum of 3 years. After 3 years in the model, a qualified direct primary care medical home practice meeting requirements can continue permanently as long as it maintains compliance. After 3 years in the model, a qualified direct primary care medical home practice meeting requirements can continue permanently as long as it maintains compliance and a majority of practices meet specified criteria for nationwide expansion. SEC. 5. USE OF DIRECT PRIMARY CARE MEDICAL HOMES UNDER MEDICARE ADVANTAGE PROGRAM. In the Medicare Advantage program, Medicare Advantage organizations can contract with qualified direct primary care medical home practices to offer primary care services and share savings. The Medicare Advantage program allows organizations to contract with qualified direct primary care medical home practices to provide primary care services and share savings. Qualified direct primary care medical home practices are defined in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.
